title: 104_hr1497
content: The Act titled "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" revises the limitation on deduction of policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for mutual life insurance companies, specifying that the deduction shall not exceed 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of taxable income, with a minimum limit of $35,000,000. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for mutual life insurance companies, specifying that the deduction shall not exceed 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of taxable income, with a minimum limit of $35,000,000. Section 809 of the Code is repealed, and the policyholders' share of tax-exempt interest is amended in section 807(a)(2). The amendments made by the "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" include changes to tax-exempt interest in various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, with effective date for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994. The Act also repeals section 809 of the Code. The limitation on loss carrybacks for life insurance companies under section 808(b)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code prevents capital losses from being carried to taxable years before January 1, 1995. Small life insurance companies are exempt from capitalizing certain policy acquisition expenses starting in 1995. Congress intends for any increased revenues from these changes to be used for deficit reduction, tax incentives for small life insurance companies, and programs benefiting children.
